description: Grow Your Portfolio as a Software Engineer. Learn about Object Oriented Design in four project-based courses.
learning_outcomes: Students will master object-oriented design principles, applying them through project-based courses. They will gain skills in Java programming and build a portfolio showcasing their software engineering abilities.
prerequisites: Basic programming knowledge recommended, ideally in any language; familiarity with fundamental computer science concepts.
price: This is a subscription-based specialization. Please check the Coursera website for pricing details.
title: Object Oriented Programming in Java Specialization

description: Learn the language of Computer Science. Learn the math that defines computer science, and practice applying it through mathematical proofs and Python code

prerequisites: Basic understanding of high school math, including algebra. Familiarity with basic programming concepts is helpful.
price: Free to audit. Paid subscription for graded assignments and certificate.
title: Introduction to Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science Specialization

description: Learn more about decentralized finance.. Understand the infrastructure of decentralized finance and assess opportunities in this space as well as screen out ideas that are likely to fail.
learning_outcomes: Understand the infrastructure of DeFi and assess opportunities within it. Learn to identify and avoid potentially unsuccessful ideas in the DeFi space.
prerequisites: Basic understanding of finance and some familiarity with blockchain technology is recommended.
price: Course enrollment costs vary. Check Coursera for specific pricing details.
title: Decentralized Finance (DeFi): The Future of Finance Specialization

prerequisites: Basic computer literacy. No prior programming experience required.
price: Free to Audit. Paid certificate available.
title: Java Programming and Software Engineering Fundamentals Specialization

learning_outcomes: Understand blockchain technology and its applications. Learn about smart contracts, Ethereum, and decentralized application development. Develop skills in Solidity and blockchain-related tools.
prerequisites: Basic programming knowledge is recommended. Familiarity with computer science fundamentals is helpful.
price: Pricing varies. Check Coursera for specific subscription or individual course fees.

description: Cyber Security. An introduction to modern information and system protection technology and methods.
learning_outcomes: Understand fundamental cybersecurity concepts, including threats, vulnerabilities, and defense mechanisms. Learn about cryptography, risk assessment, and common cyber attacks. Gain knowledge of information security practices.
prerequisites: Basic computer literacy and familiarity with operating systems are recommended. No prior cybersecurity knowledge is required.
price: Free to audit, Paid for certificate and graded assignments.
title: Introduction to Cyber Security Specialization

description: Cybersecurity Fundamentals. Construction of Secure Systems
learning_outcomes: This specialization teaches cybersecurity fundamentals and secure system construction. Learn about software testing, cryptography, and penetration testing to build and maintain secure systems.
prerequisites: Basic computer literacy and a fundamental understanding of computer science concepts are recommended. No prior cybersecurity experience is required.
price: Free to Audit. Paid subscription required for graded assignments and certificates.
title: Cybersecurity Specialization

description: Cryptography is an indispensable tool for protecting information in computer systems. In this course you will learn the inner workings of cryptographic systems and how to correctly use them in real-world applications. The course begins with a detailed discussion of how two parties who have a shared secret key can communicate securely when a powerful adversary eavesdrops and tampers with traffic. We will examine many deployed protocols and analyze mistakes in existing systems. The second half of the course discusses public-key techniques that let two parties generate a shared secret key. Throughout the course participants will be exposed to many exciting open problems in the field and work on fun (optional) programming projects. In a second course (Crypto II) we will cover more advanced cryptographic tasks such as zero-knowledge, privacy mechanisms, and other forms of encryption.
learning_outcomes: Understand the principles of cryptography, including symmetric-key and public-key techniques. Learn to analyze cryptographic protocols and identify vulnerabilities.  Gain experience with practical applications of cryptography.
prerequisites: Basic understanding of computer science concepts and programming fundamentals. Familiarity with mathematical notation is helpful.
price: Free
title: Cryptography I

description: This course covers a wide variety of IT security concepts, tools, and best practices. It introduces threats and attacks and the many ways they can show up. We’ll give you some background of encryption algorithms and how they’re used to safeguard data. Then, we’ll dive into the three As of information security: authentication, authorization, and accounting. We’ll also cover network security solutions, ranging from firewalls to Wifi encryption options. The course is rounded out by putting all these elements together into a multi-layered, in-depth security architecture, followed by recommendations on how to integrate a culture of security into your organization or team.
learning_outcomes: Understand IT security concepts, threats, and attacks. Learn about encryption, authentication, authorization, and accounting. Explore network security solutions and how to build a multi-layered security architecture.
prerequisites: Basic computer literacy and familiarity with networking concepts are recommended but not strictly required. A general understanding of IT terminology is helpful.
price: Free to audit, paid certificate available
title: IT Security: Defense against the digital dark arts

description: Decentralized Finance: The Future of Finance is a set of four courses taught by Campbell R. Harvey (Professor of Finance at the Fuqua School of Business, Duke University, and a Research Associate of the National Bureau of Economic Research) that focus on decentralized finance (DeFi). In this first course, we begin by exploring the origins of DeFi and take a broad historical view from the earliest barter economies, such as the first peer-to-peer exchanges of bartering, to present day. The course also looks at historical examples of money having value even though it is not officially backed.
learning_outcomes: Understand the origins of DeFi and its historical context, tracing the evolution of finance from barter economies to modern day. Analyze examples of value in money beyond official backing.
prerequisites: Basic understanding of financial concepts is helpful, but not strictly required. Familiarity with computers and the internet is assumed.
price: Free to audit, paid certificate available
title: Decentralized Finance (DeFi) Infrastructure

description: This course will introduce you to the foundations of modern cryptography, with an eye toward practical applications.
learning_outcomes: Understand the principles of modern cryptography, including encryption, decryption, and digital signatures. Learn about practical applications and the underlying mathematical foundations.
prerequisites: Basic understanding of mathematics (e.g., algebra)
Familiarity with programming concepts
price: Free to Audit
title: Cryptography

description: This course introduces the basics of cyber defense starting with foundational models such as Bell-LaPadula and information flow frameworks. These underlying policy enforcements mechanisms help introduce basic functional protections, starting with authentication methods. Learners will be introduced to a series of different authentication solutions and protocols, including RSA SecureID and Kerberos, in the context of a canonical schema.
learning_outcomes: Learners will understand foundational cyber defense models like Bell-LaPadula and information flow frameworks. They will be able to identify and analyze different authentication solutions including RSA SecureID and Kerberos.
prerequisites: Basic understanding of computer systems and networking concepts is recommended.
price: Free
title: Cyber Attack Countermeasures

description: Build on the software engineering skills you learned in “Java Programming: Solving Problems with Software” by learning new data structures. Use these data structures to build more complex programs that use Java’s object-oriented features. At the end of the course you will write an encryption program and a program to break your encryption algorithm.
learning_outcomes: Upon completion, students will be able to utilize data structures to build complex Java programs, including an encryption program and an algorithm to break it.
prerequisites: Java Programming: Solving Problems with Software or equivalent experience in Java programming.
price: Free
title: Java Programming: Arrays, Lists, and Structured Data

description: In this first course of the specialization, we will discuss the limitations of the Internet for business and economic activity, and explain how blockchain technology represents the way forward. After completing this course, you will be able to explain what blockchain is, how it works, and why it is revolutionary. You will learn key concepts such as mining, hashing, proof-of-work, public key cryptography, and the double-spend problem. You’ll be able to describe seven design principles for blockchain technology, and the challenges facing the people developing it. You’ll also meet the players in the blockchain ecosystem, and consider your own role in stewarding the blockchain revolution.
learning_outcomes: Understand blockchain fundamentals, its revolutionary impact, and key concepts like mining, cryptography, and the double-spend problem. Learn design principles and the blockchain ecosystem.
prerequisites: Basic understanding of computers and the internet is recommended. No prior programming or blockchain experience required.
price: Free to Audit. Paid Certificate Available.
title: Introduction to Blockchain Technologies

description: Build key skills needed to recognize common security threats and risks. Discover the characteristics of cyber-attacks and learn how organizations employ best practices to guard against them.
learning_outcomes: Upon completion, learners will be able to identify common security threats, understand cyber-attack characteristics, and recognize best practices for organizational cybersecurity.
prerequisites: Basic computer literacy and a general understanding of the internet.
price: Free
title: Introduction to Cybersecurity Essentials

description: Build on the software engineering skills you learned in “Java Programming: Solving Problems with Software” by learning new data structures. Use these data structures to build more complex programs that use Java’s object-oriented features. At the end of the course you will write an encryption program and a program to break your encryption algorithm.
learning_outcomes: Learn to use new data structures in Java, including arrays and lists, to build more complex programs. Students will implement an encryption program and break their own algorithm, solidifying their understanding of object-oriented features.
prerequisites: Java Programming: Solving Problems with Software or equivalent experience in Java programming, including basic programming concepts like variables, loops, and functions.
price: Free to Audit, Paid Certificate Available
title: Java Programming: Arrays, Lists, and Structured Data

description: A prominent expert in the number theory Godfrey Hardy described it in the beginning of 20th century as one of the most obviously useless branches of Pure Mathematics”. Just 30 years after his death, an algorithm for encryption of secret messages was developed using achievements of number theory. It was called RSA after the names of its authors, and its implementation is probably the most frequently used computer program in the world nowadays. Without it, nobody would be able to make secure payments over the internet, or even log in securely to e-mail and other personal services. In this course we will start with the basics of the number theory and get to cryptographic protocols based on it. By the end, you will be able to apply the basics of the number theory to encrypt and decrypt messages, and to break the code if one applies RSA carelessly. You will even pass a cryptographic quest!
learning_outcomes: Upon completion, students will be able to apply number theory basics to encrypt and decrypt messages. They will also learn to identify vulnerabilities in RSA and complete a cryptographic quest.
prerequisites: Basic understanding of mathematics and algebra is recommended.
price: Free
title: Number Theory and Cryptography

description: This first course of the Blockchain specialization provides a broad overview of the essential concepts of blockchain technology – by initially exploring the Bitcoin protocol followed by the Ethereum protocol – to lay the foundation necessary for developing applications and programming. You will be equipped with the knowledge needed to create nodes on your personal Ethereum blockchain, create accounts, unlock accounts, mine, transact, transfer Ethers, and check balances.
learning_outcomes: Upon completion, you'll be able to create Ethereum nodes, manage accounts, mine, and transact with Ethers. You'll also understand Bitcoin and Ethereum protocols and fundamental blockchain concepts.
prerequisites: Basic understanding of computer science concepts and some familiarity with programming is recommended.
price: Free
title: Blockchain Basics

description: In this first course of the specialization, we will discuss the limitations of the Internet for business and economic activity, and explain how blockchain technology represents the way forward. After completing this course, you will be able to explain what blockchain is, how it works, and why it is revolutionary. You will learn key concepts such as mining, hashing, proof-of-work, public key cryptography, and the double-spend problem. You’ll be able to describe seven design principles for blockchain technology, and the challenges facing the people developing it. You’ll also meet the players in the blockchain ecosystem, and consider your own role in stewarding the blockchain revolution.
learning_outcomes: Understand blockchain technology, its functionality, and significance. Learn key concepts like mining, hashing, and public key cryptography. Identify design principles and challenges within the blockchain ecosystem.
prerequisites: None. Basic understanding of the internet and general business concepts recommended.
price: Free to Audit. Paid option available for graded assignments and certificate.

description: This course discusses the limitations of the Internet for business and economic activity and explains how blockchain technology represents the way forward. After completing this course, you will be able to explain what blockchain is, how it works, and why it is revolutionary. You will learn key concepts such as mining, hashing, proof-of-work, public key cryptography, and the double-spend problem. You’ll be able to describe seven design principles for blockchain technology, and the challenges facing the people developing it. By the end of this course, you’ll learn how and why transacting on the blockchain can help us bring about a future that is faster, fairer, and more distributed than the world we inhabit today.
learning_outcomes: Understand blockchain technology, its revolutionary aspects, and key concepts like mining and cryptography. Describe blockchain design principles and challenges, and the potential for future transactions.
